Hello Knicks30,I'm one of those non-doctors who may be able to help you sort out what's going on 'til you see your doctor.I'm aware of two ways to measure blood glucose (bg)  or blood sugar.  The results mean about the same thing, but I think that "normal" in one is slightly different than in the other.  BG can be measured in whole blood or blood plasma.  A random reading of 88 in either is a normal reading.  110 or 115 can be normal too, if it's not a fasting number.  You mentioned the American Diabetes Association website.  There (www.diabetes.org) they have a nice set of tables that give the ranges for normal, pre-diabetic, and diabetic.It's super super super that you're shedding pounds and beginning to exercise.  It's important to check in with your doctor about your blood pressue (bp) , however.  In general exercise can help lower our bp and our bg and yet it can be harmful if our bodies aren't yet ready for it.I encourage you to check in wiht your doc and tell him/her that you're concerned about your bp.  S/he will likely want you to get a blood pressure cuff so you can learn to do tests thru-out the day to see how things are going.  I wouldn't be surprised if s/he also wanted to start you on bp meds.The vision complaints might be bp related, especially if you have some dizziness or shortness of breath.  BP is not something to ignore.Vision irregularities can be related to bg also, but it sounds as tho' you're doing so well at keeping yours in normal ranges, I'd be surprised if your bg is the cause.  There are also plenty of eye related issues that may make it worthwhile for you to make an appt with an eye doctor.  You may be able to start with an optomotrist (but not an optician);  diabetics are urged to be followed by a opthalmologist (a physician who specializes in eye stuff and is trained in more depth than than optomotrists).The threat of diabetes is frightening indeed.  I hope that with your motivation and your terrific progress on making good lifestyle choices, you'll stave it off.You asked "how long" could one keep diabetes at bay such that you wouldn't need medication to help control it.  It's an interesting question that's tough to answer.  I know one fellow who is "technically" diabetic (once a diabetic, you're always a diabetic; research has not yet found a cure).  He began (as you have) a rigorous weight loss and gradually increasing exercise program.  He has been diabetic now for 3 years and is not on meds.  His bgs are within normal ranges.  He is *not* cured, however.  If he were to lessen his routine his numbers would rise.  There is always a chance that even with his rigorous commitment, his pancreas will continue to be stressed to the point it needs help (in the form of either oral meds, insulin or both).I know another fellow who was diagnosed about that long ago also.  He fixed his diet and has committed to exercise.  He is now at a healthy weight for his height.  His numbers are normal and he, too, is still a type 2 diabetic.  Just a few weeks ago, he asked his doctor if he could start on insulin because he'd noticed that his fasting bg had crept up in recent months from 90s - low 100s to 110s-120s.  He did nothing "wrong" to himself to cause that rise.  His body just needs more help than his diet & exercise has afforded him.Hope this helps allay some of the fears.  Do check in with your doctor and simply *insist* on good medical care.  At 19, you can look forward to 80 years of a good life if you continue the good progress you're making already.  You deserve a good doctor to work with you.

Hi again, Knicks -Please know that your comments & questions are welcome here.  I am certain that the questions you have are shared by the many many folks who read this board without ever posting.102 is a perfectly normal bg for middle of the day.Feeling sick after exercise can be a sign of being too low or too high -- or being physically unready for the workout.  It might also be related to blood pressure issues.I'm glad you invested in the tester & strips.  You'll gain a lot of insight into what your body is telling you AND you'll have good data to share with your doctor.  Your instincts are good already -- to think about testing when you feel lousy.  That's what diabetics are taught to do, also.If you happen to test and see numbers below 70, you should treat those with quick-acting carbohydrates.  Ideally, 15gm of glucose in the form of pure glucose (jel or tabs).  Glucose tabs are relatively expensive compared to other almost-as-quick acting sources of carbos like: lifesaver candies, jelly beans, juice.  The key is to control the amount we take to treat a low.  Most foods in the US now have nutrition labels that tell us the serving size & the carbos per serving.  To treat a low, we should avoid things that slow the action of the carbo.  Protein & fat slows the action of carbos, so we shouldn't treat a low with yummy treats like chocolate candy, a sandwich, or cookies that all have ingredients besides the quick-acting carbos.Soooo, Knicks30.  You're on the road to feeling better and being in better health.  I have a feeling your doc is gonna be impressed with your progress so far.  Do talk to him/her about your bp also.Until you post again, take good care of you (and try to be patient with yourself, too).  I hope you keep reading on this forum and posting questions & comments as they arise.  There's lots of good info shared here.

Hey Knicks -You'll probably hear from others, too, so keep checking.Up to 110 has been the traditional cutoff.  In recent years, research has apparently revealed that it's safer to consider below-100 as really normal.  Given that there's testing variation, however, I'm sure your doc is most interested in trends over time.Blood sugar changes not only in 3 months, but often within 3 minutes!  That's right!  Folks with diabetes are taught to test often and many of us test 5-8 times a day because many things affect our bg:What we eatExerciseStress (good stress like a surprise party or bad stress ...)Health or illnessand some of us joke that gnomes & gremlins play a role, too, when we see changes that we cannot explain with other stuff.It just occurred to me that you might like to ask your doc for a prescription for a blood test meter & strips, so you can begin to track your own bgs.  It takes a little practice, but in no time, you'll be a pro.  Then you can see for yourself the big impact that your exercise & food choices will have in the span of a day.  Over time, you'll know your body's responses & may not test very often.  Some borderline diabetics will test a lot for a while to learn their patterns, and once they figure out how to stay in the "good numbers zone" then test occasionally to see if the patterns still hold.Remember it is *normal* for bg to rise after a meal.  It is normal for it to come back down within 2-3 hours.  Some borderline diabetics find that while their numbers do come down, it takes 3-5 or more hours to do so.  That might signal an impaired insulin response (meaning that your body may not squirt out enuf insulin soon enuf to bring your bg down).  It is also the case that folks who're overweight -- almost by definition -- have insulin resistance.  Your body is making lots of insulin but somehow the fat cells interfere with its action.  In time, as you continue to shed weight, you pancreas won't have to make so much insulin since you'll gradually get rid of your insulin resistance.  With your weight loss already, you've taken a lot of stress off your insulin-making cells already, too.There's a lot to absorb so be patient with yourself and keep accumulating more knowledge on how to take good care of you.  You're clearly a very bright young man and so I think you'll master what you need just fine.  You might like to print out the responses you get to share with your doc.  That way, s/he can correct or comment on any of the stuff we're saying here -- as it applies to your particulars.Take good care!

Hello knicks30.  Sorry for the delay in responding to your thread.  LRS answered wonderrully below.  I agree that it is wonderful that you are taking better care of yourself and are aware of all the health complications that come with being overweight.  Keep up the good work and please check in with your doctor on a regular basis.  Weight loss and a great change in acitivity can reak havoc on your body, so your doctor may have some good advice for you on those fronts.One thing I would like to add is that a BG of 107 is nothing to worry about.  Even though most doctors now are saying that anything below 100 is normal, that doesn't take into account the fact that home testing meters can be up to 15-20% on the high side.  So keep doing what you are doing, and talk to your doctor about your post-workout sickness.
